Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Advancing Undergraduate Chemistry Education with Dynamic Open-Access ChemWiki HyperTextbooks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This hyper textbook project is a team effort led by the University of California at Davis with participation by Sonoma State University, Diablo Valley College, Contra Costa Community College, Hope College, and University of Minnesota at Morris. The partnership is developing, delivering and expanding transformative content for chemistry education within a single, integrated online resource known as The ChemWiki. The ChemWiki is organized around a collaborative approach to chemistry education where an Open Access textbook is constantly being written and re-written, partly by students and partly by faculty, resulting in a no-fee, high-quality textbook, accessible anytime, anywhere, by anyone with internet access. The ChemWiki is enabling Wikitexts to be created by individual faculty by ordering modular content in a way that is meeting localized needs, and is allowing other Core Modules to be modified via an embedded graphical editor, and then incorporated into the Wikitext. The ever growing list of Wikitexts is available for anyone to peruse, adapt and adopt as needs dictate. The ChemWiki is incorporating a separate application, the 'Student Ability Rating and Inquiry System' (SARIS) that is addressing the need for student practice, by incorporating an extensive question database augmented with links to the ChemWiki core material. SARIS is providing quiz and homework questions, drawn from a deep pool, and is providing students with immediate formative feedback designed to enhance their problem-solving skills.

The ChemWiki is enabling student participatory learning by engaging them in the content construction. The nature of The ChemWiki modular concept is permitting content to be used and re-used in multiple courses at multiple levels. The open and dynamic nature of The ChemiWiki is allowing both straightforward error correction and timely content with near instantaneous modification possible for state-of-the-art material. The multiple author construction approach is enhancing usage flexibility by the very nature of the breadth of strategies employed. Finally, the inter-institutional development scheme is leading to a product of distinct value across a broad swath of institutions of higher education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ChemWiki is a collaborative approach toward chemistry education where an Open Access textbook environment is constantly being written and re-written partly by students and partly by faculty members to result in a free and eventual high-quality chemistry textbook to supplant conventional paper-based books. Rapidly rising undergraduate fees and textbook costs are factors impeding access to higher education for many students, especially those from under-served and at-risk populations, which the open access nature of the ChemWiki directly addresses. The initial construction, dissemination, evaluation, and adoption of the ChemWiki was supported with an exploratory Type I DUE-TUES award to a development team of six investigators at six campuses: Delmar Larsen (UCD), Ron Rusay (DVC), Brent Krueger (Hope College), Leverett Smith (Contra Costa Community College), Steve Farmer (Sonoma State University), and Tim Soderberg (University of Minnesota at Morris). This support was highly instrumental in the development of the ChemWiki.

The intellectual merit of the proposed effort was to address the rising textbook costs by involving greater engagement of students in their education by contributing to the ChemWiki content development and assessment. To this end, thousands of students collaboratively contributed with tens of faculty toward building the ChemWiki as a dynamic, open-access collection of resources to substitute for conventional paper-based chemistry textbooks across a broad range of courses in post-secondary education. The construction efforts were successful and the resulting free textbooks were evaluated positively (discussed below).

The key broader impact goal of the ChemWiki project is to integrate an open-access Chemistry textbook environment into the education curricula of students encompassing a broad range of skill levels and academic levels including two-year, four-year and University students. Over the past two years of development, the ChemWiki is being optimized to address a range classes at community colleges, four-year colleges, and universities and has been used as the exclusive textbook in ten different classes involving seven different instructors over four campuses with many more in discussions. Students in these courses have saved approximately $700,000 in textbook costs.

Key highlights of the results of this award over the two years of support include:

Significant growth of the ChemWiki with an increase of 9,000 pages (15,380 total) over the lifetime of the TUES grant. This effectively doubles the size of the ChemWiki from the pre-award level.

Strong dissemination of the ChemWiki with over 2.8 million daily "impressions" (number of times pages from the ChemWiki appeared in Google search results) and 200,000 daily visitors. The ChemWiki served 99,787,272 pageviews since 2008 with an average of 1.66 minutes per visit (underestimated since one-page visits do not contribute to this average), which resulted in 315 years of confirmed reading.

The ChemWiki has been exponentially growing and currently reaches over 4 million students per month (Figure 1, left). To the best of our knowledge, the ChemWiki is the most visited chemistry website in the world with traffic extending over both the United State (55%) and to every nation of the world.

The efficacy of ChemWiki was evaluated in a multi-class pilot study at UCD (Figure 1, right).
